Good catch. I was trying to understand whether we could just run the merge function once only early on in the stack (early in the view perhaps). I'm ok merging this as-is as well. 

Whatever we do we should make sure that this feature will work as expected and show the `altered` tag shows when loading a slice from a filtered dash (I think it would work either way):
https://github.com/apache/incubator-superset/pull/3668

https://github.com/apache/incubator-superset/issues/3824

Yes...I too got this problem.
I am working with Superset 0.19.0.  I am using superset as iframe inside my project. The problem is that the superset page is taking more time to load.  Is the problem with Gunicorn webserver? I have changed the worker type of gunicorn from sync to async and tried with eventlet and gevent. Still, it takes more time to load. How can I optimize the speed. Thanks in advance.

Hi  

I also have the same problem.  

I worked after fixing it like this.  
It is workaround.  
I do not understand the implementation of it, so I can not fix it.  

/superset/connectors/sqla/views.py
L.237  
```diff
         # Fail before adding if the table can't be found
-        if not table.database.has_table(table):  
+       try:
+           table.get_sqla_table_object()         
+       except Exception as e:
             raise Exception(_( 
```

### Superset version
0.20.5

### Actual results
An error message  
`Table [OracleScheme.ViewName] could not be found please double check your database connection, schema, and table name`

Thanks.
"Loaded your LOCAL configuration at [./pythonpath/superset_config.pyc]" -- Yes...I can find this line on starting superset service.
"At Airbnb we use the ORM as an API since we're writing things in Python." -- Does this mean ,it is impossible to create user by api??
Nope, dup of #3799 which should be open and has a hint of a patch. Looks like the test connection code is broken.
Aren't table datasources? Ok so you want row permissions and you can create a view with sqllab with the filter you need.

Thanks Mistercrunch and xrmx for your inputs. 

I am using Windows and this issue is only with the test connection. 

While trying to directly save the connection I got the following message

'twophase' is an invalid keyword argument for this function

which was resolved by installing pip install cx_Oracle==5.1.3
This may have been fixed in master in b059506afad33611664aa62b3ef43175828e6764 where we are checking for database being null.

Hi, I had the same problem when I was trying to connect to MySQL database in ubuntu 16.04 in amazon instance.
python3.5+Ubuntu 16.04.3+MySQL5.7
Thanks to xrmx, saving the connection before testing the connection works well

Thanks @xrmx for pointing me to this PR.
Bugfix #3736 definitely is the culprit of this issue.

I'm not sure how to handle this situation, as simply reverting #3736 would of course bring back #3208.
I guess, the cleanest approach would be to distinguish if the time column provided is an existing table column, or if there is an _Expression_ behind it. But _where_ would this be done best?

Ideas would be welcome; @Ryanthegiantlion, what do you think about this?

@williaster I addressed your comments except for `setState` where I think we should stick with the way it's now, and for the spread operator where I think it's out of scope for this PR but I think we should totally remove `Object.assign` from our code base.

Providing a MWE:

Take an arbitrary table and add a calculated column with, e.g., the following _Expression_
```
now()::timestamp
```
and make it a temporal one.

Then try to create a time series line chart with time grain of, e.g. _week_, using this colum as time column.

## Short update on superset 0.20.5:

In SQLLab the issue ist still present:

```
[2017-11-12 21:25:03,039: ERROR/ForkPoolWorker-18] zip argument #2 must support iteration
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/opt/apps/superset/venv_superset_0.20.5/lib64/python3.4/site-packages/superset/sql_lab.py", line 94, in get_sql_results
    ctask, query_id, return_results, store_results, user_name)
  File "/opt/apps/superset/venv_superset_0.20.5/lib64/python3.4/site-packages/superset/sql_lab.py", line 241, in execute_sql
    'data': cdf.data if cdf.data else [],
  File "/opt/apps/superset/venv_superset_0.20.5/lib64/python3.4/site-packages/superset/dataframe.py", line 52, in data
    return self.__df.to_dict(orient='records')
  File "/opt/apps/superset/venv_superset_0.20.5/lib64/python3.4/site-packages/pandas/core/frame.py", line 898, in to_dict
    for row in self.values]
  File "/opt/apps/superset/venv_superset_0.20.5/lib64/python3.4/site-packages/pandas/core/frame.py", line 898, in <listcomp>
    for row in self.values]
TypeError: zip argument #2 must support iteration
```

### How to reproduce

```
select current_timestamp
```

or equivalently
```
select now()
```

It is definitely caused by the combination of date and timezone, since the following selects work without any problems:

Time with timezone:
```
select current_time
```

Timestamp without timezone:
```
select localtimestamp
```
or
```
select now()::timestamp
```

### Impact
In our configuration (Postgres, Celery backend for SQLLab, Redis Cache) this bug manages to paralyze SQLLab for quite some time, hindering subsequent queries to succeed.
Thanks a lot, according to your answer, I resolve the problem. Just in Datasource-->Tables, add table can create a view, awesome!

@rumbin It seems a problem that at query time we cannot tell if a column is indeed a database column or a database expression. Unfortunately I am not familiar with sql alchemy to know how to handle this offhand. There is a meta data prop on the baseclass: https://github.com/apache/incubator-superset/blob/500455fc72dc58f9c0bd32d2b3b4da9a915bfb8c/superset/db_engine_specs.py#L72, so perhaps that can be used.

I will have a go at creating a PR that can handle both cases this week. If a fix cannot be provided it probably makes sense to revert the change. There is a workaround for #3208 - just create a view with properties cased correctly. It is a tedious workaround though, especially if every timestamp in the DB is cased 'createdAt', so it would be nice to keep the fix . . .

Agreed, single over double quotes.

Personally I prefer switching to avoid backslashes but I feel bad making you make lots of edits.

One thing though is that I prefer not enforcing rules that linters cannot enforce, so can we get pylint to enforce it? If not we'll have to tell each person on their first PR which is annoying both on the reviewer and reviewee side...

Looks like this would do it:
https://github.com/edaniszewski/pylint-quotes
Let me know if you think I should revert + release quickly
@mistercrunch I can switch from single to double quotes for the strings which include quotes to avoid backslashes. I'll comment on the PR when the change is made.
Sweet that will be ideal. It's also consistent with how the JS linter is set up.

Now you're in a serious position to win the "Most update on Github" trophy for this week
![trophe](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/487433/32712053-4aa3cdbe-c7f7-11e7-8369-16ada641106a.jpg)
@mistercrunch `flake8` is enforcing the quoting as well; https://github.com/apache/incubator-superset/blob/master/tox.ini#L59.

I'd welcome if you reverted #3736, as ot breaks existing slices.

Users who suffer from #3208 may  until a permanent solution has been found  be advised to work around the issue by introducing a calculated temporal column with lowercased name, that simply contains the originally capitalized column name in (")-quotes as _Expression_.
We will provide Tabs for dashboard, currently under design and discussion.

It would be nice to do the slices too

> .(provide folders (or tags?!))
Good point @rumbin. That sounds like a better workaround than doing it through a view.
Yeah, just do backups

In latest react-select, dropdown height became 36px, makes our input box looks narrower. 
I don't have tricks, i just make our input box as high as 36px.

Since we use `bsSize="small"` pretty much everywhere we should try to get react-select to match this (30px I think). 

Related:
https://github.com/apache/incubator-superset/pull/3850

I think that will create other problems like what's here being addressed here (inconsistent sizing between buttons and form controls):
https://github.com/apache/incubator-superset/pull/3850

The notion of `bsSize="small"` is consistent across bootstrap (control input, buttons, ...). We've been using `bsSize="small"` pretty much everywhere too.

If we want react-select to match the size of form inputs, we should make a small react-select, or move to not using `bsSize="small"`.
I think this open PR solves this: https://github.com/apache/incubator-superset/pull/3583
@john-bodley let me know if you want me to merge this once the conflicts are resolved.
